result.execSummary:
The defendant Joseph A Tauschek was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Joseph A Tauschek is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Joseph A Tauschek was found guilty of Possession of THC (2nd+ Offense), a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(e).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes:
Defendant to pay all court costs, supervision fees and any costs of treatment as a condition of probation.  If probation is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, in addition to all other enforcement sanctions available to the court, a civil judgment enforceable by all creditors' remedies shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.
Attorney fees payable back to Ozaukee County.
Defendant is granted privileges set forth in Wis Stats 303.08

Defendant to submit to random testing.
submit DNA
Defendant to participate in drug and/or alcohol counseling and treatment deemed appropriate by DOC and to pay all costs of treatment.

Defendant Joseph A Tauschek in court with attorney Michael Girard Penkwitz.  Patti l Wabitsch appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Plea of guilty to count 1. State moves to dismisss count 2.   Court accepts plea, finds the defendant guilty and renders sentence. Court advised the defendant pursuant to Wisconsin Statutes Section 973.176, that as a convicted felon she/he may no longer use or possess any firearms or body armor; also she/he may not vote in any election until their civil rights have been restored.
Plea/sentencing hearing on January 12, 2015 at 08:30 am.
